column4: my file doesn't have one
how do you mean?

well, say I want to use mplayer to play a file, I type 'mplayer' and then the beginning of the file name followed by TAB so that it completes the name. However, I discovered that ubuntu uses a file called '/etc/bash_completion' that restricts the file names that get completed according to their extension. For instance I can use the auto completion if my file name is for instance 'file.mpg', but not if it's just
if the file is in the current directory you must use ./
that doesn't work
is the fileexecutable?
so you can type mplay<tab> ./somef<tab>
I'm not actually typing tab
but as I said, this doesn't work if the file doesn't have one of the extensions specified for mplayer in '/etc/bash_completion'
I thought it just read the files locally and suggested
no, it apparently doesn't work like that on ubuntu (I'm a recent convert from fedora). That's an interesting feature I think, but I'm looking for a way to temporarily bypass it
i tab everything just fine, ive never heard of thisbash file before you told me
well, try to mplayer some file with no extension. It shouldn't work
im at work on xp, sorry
how do you mean? Like dont type the file extension of the file?
or does your file not have one
it knows by parsing the file
it doesn't
well, you can't always do that. For instance, if you want to play the temporary flv files that you get when you're browsing a site with videos like youtube, these files are named FlashXXXX in /tmp/
